awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Data Science Across Disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
It is now well established that there is a critical need for researchers who can think creatively to solve problems in data science in various interdisciplinary fields. Further, there is a scarcity of workforce and opportunities to train the next generation of researchers to tackle the problems in data science. To address the scarcity, this Data Science Across Disciplines Research Experiences for Undergraduates (DSAD-REU) Site will immerse undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary research-intensive training and mentoring program. The impacts of this site will extend beyond the project duration in a number of ways. First, students will be exposed to a variety of data science research projects that are bound to stimulate passion for data science research and help them seek either industry careers and/or graduate degrees in this area. Second, the site students will serve as peer mentors and brand ambassadors for data science research at their home institution to bring more awareness to the field. Finally, it will open students to vast opportunities in academia, industry and government.

The objectives of the DSAD-REU are that students will participate in data science research in different domains such as healthcare, social science, and exercise science. The students’ participation in data science research will lead to outcomes such as: (1) increased confidence in their ability to carry out a data science research project; (2) improved ability to apply abstract concepts learned in the classroom to actual applications; and (3) increased competence in verbal and written communication of research findings and experience to a diverse audience. It is important to provide the requisite background to undergraduate students who may have little or no background research experience in data science related areas. Hence, a 3-day mini boot camp on introduction to data science will be offered during the first week of the program. The program is composed of interesting projects in the broad field of data science across different disciplines, whose purpose is to arouse the intellectual curiosity, challenge the students to develop novel solutions that will advance the state-of-art, and improve oral and written communication skills.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Our REU site provided an interdisciplinary research-intensive training and mentoring of undergraduate students in the broad field of data science across different disciplines. The interdisciplinary nature of the site is crucial as it gave the students a chance to experience the possibilities of data science impact across different disciplines under one site. Also, many of the intellectual, social and practical problems require the creative thinking that typically emerges from interdisciplinary fields. This site was intentional in encouraging students to interact with fellow students who are working in data science across different domains.

Stated recruitment goals from the REU site were to encourage students from underrepresented groups to apply, to accept at least 70% of site-funded fellows from outside the Marquette community, and to give preference to students with little research experience or opportunity from their home institution. We received 335 applications for program years 2020-2023 and accepted 53 REU fellows into the program of which 35 were supported by NSF dollars and the rest (n=18) were supported by internal and external faculty grants. Accepted REU fellows were 19/ 53 (36%) female,  and 10/53 (19%) non-white or Hispanic/Latino. 27 out of 35 site-funded students (77%)  were from outside the Marquette community where we gave special emphasis to recruit students who would not normally have research opportunities at their home institutions. Example home universities were : Bucknell, Siena College, Simmons, Valparaiso, University of La Verne, University of Puerto Rico, St. Olaf College, Lindenwood, Carleton, Juniata, Swarthmore College, Saint Norbert College, Alverno, Mount Holyoke, and Mount Mary.

Eleven individuals responded to a follow-up longitudinal survey. Seven of them are in graduate school, three are employed in private companies,  and one with a MBA and currently is employed as a programmer analyst in a private sector. Those who are in graduate school, two are in PhD program and  five are in the master’s program. Since the survey, we know of two more students who enrolled in a PhD program bringing the total to four enrolled in a PhD program.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the REU site is on applying abstract concepts and technologies to advance data science research across disciplines in a variety of projects. The intellectual merits of the research projects are embedded in the project descriptions available at : https://reu.cs.mu.edu/index.php/Main_Page

The research productivity was at a high level, with eighteen of the REU students publishing papers in peer-reviewed conferences/journals. This was especially impressive considering we had a pandemic to deal with in the first two years of running the program in 2020 (virtual) and 2021 (virtual). We then moved the program back in-person in 2022 and 2023.

Broader Impacts

Aside from the direct impacts on the pipeline of students heading into both industry and academia, many of the research projects have resulted in broader societal impacts. For example, through the PUMP-CS curriculum project, REU fellows contributed to broadening access to computing in both urban and rural high schools through innovative co-design of curriculum, hardware and software tools. In the healthcare domain, REU fellows have utilized hospital records to identify key factors such as healthcare data and social determinants to predict risk of opioid use disorder, opioid overdose and length of stay. In the same domain, fellows explored the ethical and privacy implications of generating text from generative AI. In the social science domain, REU fellows developed machine learning algorithms to predict food shortages in local Wisconsin food pantries. All of the projects have used data science to affect society beyond the boundaries of  their individual research disciplines.


Last Modified: 07/05/2024
Modified by: Praveen Madiraju
